Posts.Content: lyn1117 wrote: I am very confused.  I have spoken with several oncologist on my case and I am still confused.  While they indicated no lymph node involvement (SNB 2 nodes removed), I finally received the pathology report today and it indicates cancer cells were found in the lymph nodes and vascular system.  The report says L1 and V1, which this onc tells me means that while there was no additional tumor growth in the lymph nodes that both the lymphatic system and the vascular system showed cancer cells, meaning that the cells show the ability to pass these systems (and may already have) and grow elsewhere.  I have IDC with DCIS Size 2.4cm, ER 80-90% positive and Prog 30-40% positive and Her2 positive, grade III.  They do not provide staging here in Switzerland, but from the posts, I may be stage IIa, if the nodes are not involved, but if they are it would be different???  My question (that I cant seem to understand the answer from the doctor) is that since they found microscopic cells in both places, does this mean my nodes are involved?  If so shouldnt they take more out? They indicate now I must do Chemo and then Herceptin, but no further surgery...  Any clarity from you wonderful people would be helpful and I really appreciate accessing this site and the posts it has kept me sane so far...but I feel like I am slipping as each visit to the Onc has more bad news.   thank you so!  lyn Dx IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help with Pathology Report lyn1117 2z54

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2008 10:59AM lyn1117 wrote: Beth, thank you for the information.   I am at a low point....  I have a very demanding job where they are ignoring my health issues as there are many lay offs going on and I guess they feel who can work will keep the job.  My life is falling apart as I am in Switzerland and they have no obligation to return me to home (where I own a house) and now I am virtually uninsurable.  I love my family, but I dont dare let up even through 2 oncs have told me that I must as I fear of being laid off or unable to pay bills.  I have no cognitive abilities and keep missing things I should have paid and cannot focus on the critical situations.  I have 6 kids, 5 in the states and they keep calling to see if I am fine and I put on this same clown face I use all day to show I can handle what I cannot.... My sincere apologies for laying this on this board, but it feels good to let it out.  Please understand, I have many people depending on me and now as I took this overseas assignment, I have no life insurance either!!  I am distressed and starting chemo next week.  Dont know how long I can maintain this charade.  Again, apologies, bless you for the fights you are in and the fights you have made.  One cannot understand without having the same situation facing them...I know this is why I have issues at work...  Take care and again, thanks for listening.
Posts.Title: Help with Pathology Report lyn1117 2z54

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 01:09PM lyn1117 wrote: Thank you for the response!  I do have people I work with that speak english, but none who had experience bc and there seem to be no support groups here.  It was touch and go at first as they are so respectful here yet they do not know how to comfort you that it is not the end of the world, instead they (german doctors) come off as being sad and remorseful and treating you like you are one step out of the door.  They are very kind, but have no reassuring words.  When I visited the states an onc there helped put things into perspective.  I had a lumpectomy and I am still in the hospital recovering.  The hospital is great, gourmet food and they even offer wine or beer with the dinners.   Very different from what I am used to in the states.   My daughter is handling this very well.  To cheer me up in the recovery room she invented a game, drew my face on a paper and cut out a piece of paper resembling my hair and put tape on it to have us play `pin the hair on mommy`!!!!  We have been bracing her for all that will go on on the doctor has said that I will loose my hair. Bette, good luck to you on shrinking the lump. I wish I had your skills with German!    Julie, Good to hear it is offered in the US, but I was told it is only offered in clinical trials as well as only for those people who had certain other qualifications, i.e. postmenopausal (which I am not).  Best to both of you and keep in touch!!!  lyn
Posts.Title: Just out of Surgery lyn1117 lyn1117

Posts.Content: lyn1117 wrote: Dear all,  Thank you for all of the support, I am just out of surgery yesterday, still in the hospital.  I am so glad it is over and real thankful that out of 2 nodes examined, they initially say no involvement.  They did indicate they wont know for certain until one week  My question: is this standard?  My surgery removed with clean margins a 1cm IDS.  Also, I received a treatment that is still in studies in the US, but that I could opt for here in Switzerland, intraoperative radiotherapy.  They do your first radiation treatment while you are opened up on the operating table.  This replaces the final boost that you get at the end of the radiation to the cancer position.  It has received very good results in clinical trials.  I saw an onc in the States and he had heard of it, but indicated that it is not yet available in the US and that Europe is more advanced in these studies.  Fortunately for me, I recently took a job in Switzerland and my insurance will only pay for medical care in Switzerland.  At first this made me anxious, but now I am ok with it.   As I look at my 10 year old, I am feeling much calmer and hopeful that I will be here when she gets married.   The only hard part is that I cannot find anyone over here that speaks english and is going through the same thing (and I dont speak german).  This board is my only point of contact and I thank you for letting me be a part of it.  Cheers,  lyn Dx IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just out of Surgery lyn1117 lyn1117

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2009 09:23PM lyn1117 wrote: Dear Keh, Anxiety is a very powerful thing, it just lives deep in you and won't let go sometimes.  You need to be proactive to neutralize it.  Call a doctor, get in for a consult.  Clinics that specialize in BC have genetic counselors available.  I lived through and am a survivor of bc, but after two lumpectomies (one benign, one high grade cancer) and another scary mammogram and MRI, I went for the bilateral.  I have no history in my family, but with fibroid breasts, lumps were everywhere.....Result, the tissue removed with the bilat showed no residual evidence of cancer....finally I drove out the anxiety.  Hope you will find peace by getting tested and getting answers that comfort you.  take care, lyn
Posts.Title: I could use a little help/advice Kehjj2009 kreativek

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 06:32AM lyn1117 wrote: Peeps, this was on the Oncology report after the surgery and SNB.  Peeps and econmom...I am left handed too!!  Is there a trend here??  Peeps, funny thing about the isolated cancer cells, they wrote it up as clear in lymphnodes, but then in the lymph fluid and the blood taken during surgery they found these isolated cells or micromets, which by all of their explaining, means it could have spread to other areas, it just had not stopped in the lymph nodes and started forming a cancer (grouping together)...however, my onc indicated they could move other places and start this process.  It is discouraging as it looks with 0-2 lymph nodes, that that is not possible.. yet I fear it is by their description.  I cannot find on web any clarity, some articles question not labeling lymph nodes positive if they contain isolated tumor cells, and other say there is no evidence that you have a better chance to spread.  Any knowledge or clarity on this matter would be great....  please share... (by the way, I had to read the report in detail and question my onc on this, the information was not volunteered) lyn
Posts.Title: Does chemo zap cancer in nodes... Lynette Maryiz

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 02:49AM lyn1117 wrote: I had a lumpectomy with SN Biopsy, Nodes were declared clear, but there were micromets in my lymph system (isolated cancer cells) and in my bloodstream.  After surgery I am on FEC, then I will be on Tax for 4 treatments at the same time I start Herceptin.  I asked about Gene testing and they indicated it probably is not positive so they dont do... also they are not recommending additional surgery.   They indicated the heavy chemo is systemic and will kill any others and not necessary to cause further complications.  My docs and treatment is in Zurich Switzerland, but I consulted in US as well.   I start in the ALLTO clinical trial which has Tyverb (pills) and Herceptin used in different arms of the trial.  They also have this available in the US and would recommend any HER2pos to look into it. Take care all!  lyn
Posts.Title: Does chemo zap cancer in nodes... Lynette Maryiz
